title: Laser assisted cold spray of AISI 4340 steel

extractedText.notes: Cold spray (CS) deposit without laser heating; average hardness measured from a typical CS process.
Laser-assisted cold spray (LACS) deposit achieved with in situ laser heating to a substrate surface temperature of 500°C (lowest measured hardness).
LACS deposit at 738°C under standard gas conditions; average hardness measured at the lower end (532 HV).
LACS deposit at 738°C with lowered gas temperature (475°C) and pressure (3.1 MPa), resulting in a higher average hardness (592 HV).
LACS deposit at 950°C; although microstructural evolution is described, no specific hardness value was reported (hardness returned to a normal distribution).

title: Corrosion properties of Cold-Sprayed Tantalum Coatings
Effect of Substrate Surface Roughening and Cold Spray Coating On The Fatigue Life of AA2024 specimens
Laser Assisted Cold Spray Deposition
extractedText:
The text is an extensive collection of chapters from a multi-author volume exploring cold spray technology in additive manufacturing. It covers the fundamentals and processing principles of cold spray deposition, emphasizing its solid‐state, low thermal input nature that minimizes oxidation while enabling rapid, high‐density coating build‐up. Several chapters detail how process parameters such as gas temperature, pressure, stand‐off distance, powder feed rate, particle size, and substrate properties affect deposition efficiency, microstructure evolution, and mechanical properties.

A significant portion of the text is devoted to advanced modeling and simulation tools for predicting coating build‐up. Multiple approaches are discussed, including finite element analysis, smoothed particle hydrodynamics, and morphological modeling that incorporates particle impedance, impact angle, and toolpath planning. These predictive models are intended to optimize deposition parameters to achieve desired shapes and near‐net‐shape components while minimizing post‐processing.

Other sections investigate the use of laser assistance—both co‐axial and off‐axis configurations—to improve deposition efficiency and enable the use of less expensive gases. Laser heating softens the substrate and powder particles, reducing the critical velocity for bonding and fostering improved interparticle cohesion, even for harder materials such as titanium alloys or shape memory alloys like CuAlNi. Moreover, comprehensive non‐destructive inspection methods such as Optical Coherence Tomography and laser ultrasonic testing are presented for in‐process dimensional analysis, flaw detection, and bond integrity assessment.

Collectively, the volume provides a state‐of‐the‐art review of cold spray additive manufacturing, presenting experimental results, simulation studies, and advanced inspection techniques that together offer guidelines for improved process control, material performance, and integration into industrial applications.

title: Cold Spray and Laser-Assisted Cold Spray of CrMnCoFeNi High Entropy Alloy Using Nitrogen as the Propelling Gas
Influence of Surface Temperature in the Laser Assisted Cold Spray Deposition of Sequential Oxide Dispersion Strengthened Layers: Microstructure and Hardness
Particle Deformation and Microstructure Evolution During Cold Spray of Individual Al-Cu Alloy Powder particles
Improving Inter-Particle Deformation and Bonding by Preserving Transient in-situ Deposition Temperatures During Cold Spray
How to Unleash the Remarkable Potential of Cold Spray: A Perspective
Interfacial Contact and Deformation: From All Solid State Li Batteries to the Cold Spray Refractory Ta Powders
extractedText:
The dissertation text provides a very detailed account of both modeling/simulation and experimental work in two different areas: (1) all‐solid‐state lithium battery (ASSB) interfacial contact and deformation under different stack pressures, and (2) cold spray deposition of refractory tantalum (Ta) powders on Ta and 4340 steel substrates.

Below is a summary of the key simulation and experimental results described in the text:

1. All‐Solid‐State Battery (ASSB) Results  
 • A combined analytical, computational (FEM), and experimental study was carried out on a model ASSB based on a LiBH₄–LiNH₂ solid electrolyte.  
 • The dissertation uses the Hertzian contact model (analytical) and axisymmetric finite element modeling to simulate interfacial contact between the electrolyte and the cathode. The simulations show that as the applied stack pressure increases, the contact radius improves (i.e. better interfacial contact), but the cost is an increase in localized axial and shear strains at the interface.  
 • Experimental measurements using digital image correlation (DIC) during compression tests captured local strain distributions. Initially (at 0 MPa) there is little deformation, but increasing pressure (up to 1 MPa) closes gaps and enhances contact. However, at higher pressures the imposed stresses cause significant plastic deformation and microcracking—which may eventually lower the ionic conductivity.  
 • Electrochemical tests (impedance spectroscopy and cyclic voltammetry) reveal that there is an optimum stack pressure—around 0.26 MPa—in which the electrolyte–electrode interfacial contact is maximized while induced strains remain in the elastic range. At this optimum, the measured room‐temperature ionic conductivity reaches about 9×10⁻⁵ S/cm. Pressures above this value are found to lead to increased damage (large axial/shear strains), which degrade cell performance.

2. Cold Spray (CS) of Refractory Ta Powders  
 • The work explores the role of deformation and cracking during cold spray deposition of Ta powders onto Ta and 4340 steel substrates.  
 • Experimental characterization (SEM, FIB, TEM) of the Ta powders shows that the particles are coated by a nanoscale (≈2.8 nm) amorphous TaOₓ film.  
 • Density functional theory (DFT) calculations are used to obtain the mechanical properties of top surface oxides (both for Ta and for the oxide on 4340 steel, modeled here as Fe₂O₃). These calculated properties (elastic moduli, Poisson’s ratio, tensile strength, etc.) serve as inputs for the finite element simulations.  
 • Finite element analyses (conducted in ABAQUS–Explicit) simulate the impact of a single Ta particle (with an average diameter of about 10 µm) at an impact velocity of ~680 m/s. The simulations show that high-velocity impacts generate localized temperature rises (although still below the melting point of Ta) and very high plastic strains in the particle and substrate at the contact region.  
 • The modeling also tracks the evolution of stress fields and predicts the initiation and propagation of microcracks, particularly in the oxide layers on both the particle and the substrate. In addition, parametric studies indicate that higher impact velocities and thicker oxide layers lead to a lower fraction of oxides being fractured—in other words, optimal conditions for oxide disruption (which is necessary for achieving metal-to-metal bonding) depend critically on both spray velocity and oxide thickness.

3. Overall Implications and Conclusions  
 • In the ASSB study, it is shown that moderate stack pressure is beneficial because it improves interfacial contacts and ionic conductivity, whereas too high a pressure induces damaging strains that can trigger plasticity and microcracking.  
 • In cold spray processing, controlling the oxide character (its thickness and propensity to crack) and achieving sufficient particle impact energy are both essential for promoting metallurgical bonding between the particle and the substrate.  
 • The combined experimental, analytical, and computational approaches demonstrate that optimizing mechanical loading parameters (whether in battery assembly or in cold spray deposition) is key to enhancing performance and durability.  
 • Finally, the text outlines opportunities for future work including the use of machine learning to optimize parameter effects in ASSBs and further investigation (and possible extension of computational models) into the complex thermo-mechanical behavior in high-velocity cold spray processes.

This multi-scale investigation clearly shows how interfacial contact, induced interfacial stress/strain and material degradation phenomena play a critical role in both solid–state battery performance and in the quality of cold-sprayed deposits.
